comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Obviously more research needed - do we have any other pictures at that time,from around the area State Records?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is a 1903 photo from the same viewpoint (the gas holder?) which shows trees still in situ - maybe The Tree is one of these? It seems strange to obliterate cemeteries, buildings, landscape etc, and keep one tree!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]  I know you're not suggesting a tree preservation order in 1903, but it sure looks like the same tree!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]  I didn't realise that Anthony Hordern and Sons had a shop this close to the railway station.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] I think this is just a glimpse of a warehouse (not a shop) behind the earlier Hordern's [Old] Palace Emporium in the Haymarket (destroyed by fire in 1901). Many of the large stores were clustered around the station for customers and mail-order parcel delivery convenience. See www.sydneyarchitecture.com/GON/GON01.htm .

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] Makes sense to me!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: I wonder if the tree was removed in1955 during the railways centenary -- loco No 1 was displayed in the park during the celebratioms. Worth checking the archives I reckon!

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: That was the Anthony Hordens store that was destroyed by fire in 1901. The store actually covered a number of disperate adjacent buildings between Barlow Street (then called Gipps Street) and the Capitol Theatre. There was a "Furniture Emporium" in one building, adjacent to another emporium, etc, all run by Anthony Horderns. The entire group of buildings were destroyed in one of Sydney's biggest fires. They then moved up further north to what is now World Square.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
The tree was removed in February 1936. See comments here -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6196422821/]
